Explore – GarageBand: Creating Music with Multiplication and Codes

instructions.text:
Explore GarageBand and its tools. Answer the following questions: 

  1. What do you notice when you open GarageBand? What buttons do you see? What can you do? 

  1. How do you think you navigate GarageBand to select instruments?  

  1. How do you play basic notes in GarageBand? 

  1. What are the notes of a scale?

folder.name: Plan and SMART Goal – GarageBand: Creating Music with Multiplication and Codes

instructions.text:
Before you start your challenge, make a plan for your project and set a SMART goal. Your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based. 

 

  1. How can I translate a number I have calculated into a musical code? 

  1. How will I use the code I decipher to create a song? 

  1. Write your project SMART Goal: We will use (name of kit/program) to program (detailed description product) by (due date). We are creating this because (personal interest or purpose).

folder.name: Daily Project Journal – GarageBand: Creating Music with Multiplication and Code

instructions.text:
Use this space to answer the following questions every day by collaborating with your partner - this is a group assignment. 

  1. What did we do today? 

  1. What did we learn? 

  1. What math did we use? 

  1. What could we have done differently? 

  1. What new questions do we have based on our work today/this week? 

  1. What is our plan for next time?

folder.name: Project Submission – GarageBand: Creating Music with Multiplication and Code

instructions.text:
1. Upload: 

  • Your Multiplication Problems Worksheet
  • Your Code Translation Worksheet
  • A recording of your song
  • One of the two options: 

    • Original 20-30 note song, with its notes translated to the numerical code

    • Yankee Doodle song with its notes translated to the numerical code. 

2. Reflect on the following questions: 

  • What part of this project did you like the best? Explain why.
  • What part of this project was the most challenging and how did you  overcome any difficulties?
  • How else might a musician use math when composing or playing? 

3. Revisit your SMART goal. Remember, your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.  

  • Did you meet your SMART goal? Why or why not?
  • How did you manage your time? How could you improve your time management?
  • Did you have to modify your SMART goal?
  • What will you do differently next time?

instructions.text:

instructions.text:
Before you start your challenge, make a plan for your project and set a SMART goal. Your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based. 

  1. How do ratios play a part in rhythm and music? 

  1. What kind of music vibe am I aiming for? (Funky groove, epic rock anthem, chill beats?) 

  1. What percussion instruments are available in GarageBand? 

  1. Write your project SMART Goal: We will use (name of kit/program) to program (detailed description product) by (due date). We are creating this because (personal interest or purpose).

folder.name: Project Submission – GarageBand: Rhythm of Ratios

instructions.text:
1. Upload the Keeping the Beat document. 

2. Upload the recording of your rhythm. 

3. Reflect on the following questions: 

  • Did creating rhythmic patterns based on ratios change your understanding of how music works?
  • How could you use the skills you learned in this project to analyze or create music in other genres?
  • Can you think of any real-life examples (outside of music) where understanding ratios might be useful?
  • If you were to share your music with someone else, what would you tell them about the ratios behind your rhythmic patterns? 

4. Revisit your SMART goal. Remember, your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based. 

  • Did you meet your SMART goal? Why or why not?
  • How did you manage your time? How could you improve your time management?
  • Did you have to modify your SMART goal?
  • What will you do differently next time?

instructions.text:

  1. Write your project SMART Goal: We will use (name of kit/program) to  (detailed description product) by (due date). We are creating this because (personal interest or purpose).

category.name: Animation and Drawing by Do Ink

folder.name: Explore - Animation and Drawing by Do Ink: Changing Shapes

instructions.text:
Explore Animation and Drawing by Do Ink and its tools. Answer the following questions:

  1. Look in the mirror. How does the mirror change your image? 
  2. What happens when you turn left or right? Do you change?
  3. What happens when you turn a shape? Does the shape turn?
  4. Have you ever played with a transformer? Why do you think they are called that?
  5. How do you think animated movies are made?

folder.name: Plan and SMART Goal - Animation and Drawing by Do Ink: Changing Shapes

instructions.text:
Before you start the challenge, make a plan for your project and set a SMART goal. Your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.

  1. Begin by drawing several rectangles and triangles. Practice making a small change to each shape. As you change each shape, think about the attributes of the shape (angles, lengths, size, intersections). 
    • Did any attributes change?
    • Did you rotate or transform your shapes? 
  2. Write your project SMART Goal: We will use (name of technology) to (detailed description) by (due date). We are creating this because (personal interest or purpose).

folder.name: Daily Project Journal - Animation and Drawing by Do Ink: Changing Shapes

instructions.text:
Use this space to answer the following questions every day by collaborating with your partner - this is a group assignment.

  1. What did we do today?
  2. What did we learn?
  3. What math did we use?
  4. What could we have done differently?
  5. What new questions do we have based on our work today/this week?
  6. What is our plan for next time?

folder.name: Project Submission - Animation and Drawing by Do Ink: Changing Shapes

instructions.text:
For your project submission share the following items:

  1. Upload your animation.
  2. Upload an image of your quadrilaterals. Be sure to include the names for each.
  3. All drawings used in your animation.
  4. The attributes of each shape in your drawings.
  5. Reflect on the following questions:
    • How did you use attributes of triangles and quadrilaterals in your project?
    • How did you use rotations in your project?
    • How did you use transforming shapes in your project?
    • Did the attributes of the shapes change when you moved or rotated them?
    • What change to a triangle changed it to a different shape? What are the attributes of the new shape?
    • What changes to rectangles changed them to a different shape? What are the attributes of the new shape?
  6. Revisit your SMART goal. Remember, your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.
    • Did you meet your SMART goal? Why or why not?
    • How did you manage your time? How could you improve your time management?
    • Did you have to modify your SMART goal?
    • What will you do differently next time?

folder.name: Explore - Animation and Drawing by Do Ink: Frames and Fractions

instructions.text:
Explore Animation and Drawing by Do Ink and its tools. Answer the following questions:

  1. What will you choose to animate? A scene from a story or movie? A scene from a video game? A scientific concept?
  2. What specific part of your scene will be animated?
  3. How are 10 and 100 related? How can you turn 10 into 100?
  4. Why are common denominators needed to add or subtract fractions?

folder.name: Plan and SMART Goal - Animation and Drawing by Do Ink: Frames and Fractions

instructions.text:
Before you start the challenge, make a plan for your project and set a SMART goal. Your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.

  1. Create a sketch of what you think you might animate.
  2. Watch some of the tutorial videos on the Do Ink website.
  3. How long do you want your animation to be?
  4. If the rate of frames played on Do Ink is three frames for every 1/10 of a second, think about how long you want each animation to play. How many frames will play if you want your drawing to play for 5/10 of a second? One second? How will this change your work and the viewers' experience?
  5. Find images you might want to include in your animation. Start by looking through the images and drawings that you can use that are on the camera roll on the Do Ink website.
  6. Write your project SMART Goal: We will use (name of technology) to (detailed description) by (due date). We are creating this because (personal interest or purpose).

instructions.text:

folder.name: Project Submission - Animation and Drawing by Do Ink: Frames and Fractions

instructions.text:
For your project submission share the following items:

  1. Save your animation to the camera roll.
  2. Reflect on the following questions:
    • What skills did you learn by watching the tutorials that showed how to animate the water cycle?
    • What did you choose to animate? Why did you choose to animate this?
    • What tools did you use in your animation?
    • How did you use equivalent fractions to determine how many frames per second are in an animation?
  3. Revisit your SMART goal. Remember, your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.  
    • Did you meet your SMART goal? Why or why not? 
    • How did you manage your time? How could you improve your time management? 
    • Did you have to modify your SMART goal? 
    • What will you do differently next time?

folder.name: Explore - Animation-ish: Express Yourself

instructions.text:
Explore Animation-ish and its tools. Answer the following questions:

  1. Think of an animated movie you have seen. What made it entertaining?
  2. What is a flipbook?
  3. What kinds of stories are best told with a flipbook?
  4. Could you add words to a flipbook? Why or why not?
  5. How are you able to understand what others are feeling if they haven't told you? What do you use as your cues?

folder.name: Plan and SMART Goal- Animation-ish: Express Yourself

instructions.text:
Before you start the challenge, make a plan for your project and set a SMART goal. Your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.

  1. Make a list of different feelings and draw a picture that represents each of them. You will upload this in your project submission.
  2. How is color used to represent emotion?  (For example, people often use the color red to indicate that someone is angry). 
  3. For each of the emotions that you drew, choose a color that matches the emotion. Add the colors to your list.
  4. Write your project SMART Goal: We will use (name of technology) to (detailed description) by (due date). We are creating this because (personal interest or purpose).

folder.name: Daily Project Journal - Animation-ish: Express Yourself

instructions.text:
Use this space to answer the following questions every day by collaborating with your partner - this is a group assignment.

  1. What did we do today?
  2. What did we learn?
  3. What math did we use?
  4. What could we have done differently?
  5. What new questions do we have based on our work today/this week?
  6. What is our plan for next time?

folder.name: Project Submission - Animation-ish: Express Yourself

instructions.text:
For your project submission share the following items:

  1. Upload the list of feelings, drawing and colors that you created.
  2. Upload the storyboard you created. Indicate any changes you made in your final project on the storyboard.
  3. Upload your final animation project.
  4. Reflect on the following questions:
    • Flipbooks can also be made without using technology- just using paper and pen.  What are the advantages and disadvantages to using technology to create a flipbook?
    • What other types of events could you animate using this technique for in your classes- describe in detail how it could be used in one of your classes (Social Studies, Science class, English/ Language Arts, Math, Physical Education, Music, etc.)
    • How did creating the storyboard for your project help you produce your animation? What other ways could you have prepared before making your Flipbook?
  5. Revisit your SMART goal. Remember, your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.
    • Did you meet your SMART goal? Why or why not?
    • How did you manage your time? How could you improve your time management?
    • Did you have to modify your SMART goal?
    • What will you do differently next time?

folder.name: Explore - Animation-ish: Multiplication Movie

instructions.text:
Explore Animation-ish and its tools. Answer the following questions:

  1. What is an animation? What is your favorite animation? Why is it your favorite?
  2. Do you think creating an animation is a good way to teach someone? Why or why not?
  3. What kinds of objects can you place into groups?
  4. How does placing the same number of objects into groups model skip-counting?
  5. When might you place objects into groups?

instructions.text:
Before you start the challenge, make a plan for your project and set a SMART goal. Your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.

  1. What object will you group to model multiplication?
  2. How many of each object will you start with?
  3. How many groups of each object will you animate?
  4. How many objects will be in each group?
  5. Write your project SMART Goal: We will use (name of technology) to (detailed description) by (due date). We are creating this because (personal interest or purpose).

folder.name: Project Submission - Animation-ish: Multiplication Movie

instructions.text:
For your project submission share the following items:

  1. Upload the videos of your animations modeling the Commutative and Associative Properties of Multiplication. Be sure to include the one showing multiplication as grouping. 
  2. Reflect on the following questions:
    • What was fun or challenging about making animations?
    • Do you think animations are a good way to teach new information? Why or why not?
    • How did making an animation help you better understand multiplication as grouping?
    • Think about the number of objects you started with to place into groups. Could you have animated a different grouping? Explain why or why not.
  3. Revisit your SMART goal. Remember, your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.  
    • Did you meet your SMART goal? Why or why not? 
    • How did you manage your time? How could you improve your time management? 
    • Did you have to modify your SMART goal? 
    • What will you do differently next time?

instructions.text:
Explore Arckit and its tools. Answer the following questions:

  1. What do you know about building design?
  2. What do you know about architecture?
  3. What do you know about scale models?
  4. Why do you think architects construct scale models?

folder.name: Plan and SMART Goal - Arckit: Design and Measure Community Spaces

instructions.text:
Before you start the challenge, make a plan for your project and set a SMART goal. Your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.

  1. List the purposes and needs for your community space.
  2. Brainstorm how to meet these needs and purposes through your building design. For example, if your community space needs to serve the elderly, you may decide that a single-level building is better than a multi-level with stairs.
  3. Arrange the floor pieces in different layouts to help you visualize your options.
  4. Sketch pictures of your ideas on paper.
  5. Write your project SMART Goal: We will use (name of technology) to (detailed description) by (due date). We are creating this because (personal interest or purpose).

folder.name: Daily Project Journal - Arckit: Design and Measure Community Spaces

instructions.text:
Use this space to answer the following questions every day by collaborating with your partner - this is a group assignment.

  1. What did we do today?
  2. What did we learn?
  3. What math did we use?
  4. What could we have done differently?
  5. What new questions do we have based on our work today/this week?
  6. What is our plan for next time?

folder.name: Project Submission - Arckit: Design and Measure Community Spaces

instructions.text:
For your project submission share the following items:

  1. Upload the Google Slide presentation showing the photo of your building, tape diagrams, and the math and final dimensions.
  2. Upload images of any sketches you drew. This includes brainstorming sketches and final drawings.
  3. Upload a document with details about the purpose of your community space, who will use it, the needs of your clients, and any other requirements. Explain how these requirements influenced your design.

instructions.text:

  5. What strong feelings do main characters experience in short stories?
  6. Many movies include scenes about math and science. In the movie "Matilda," the main character stunned her teacher and classmates when she was able to mentally calculate 13 x 379. Can you think of a movie or a book that incorporated math into the story?

Open the Blockly App and explore the coding blocks. As you explore, think about these questions:

  1. What types of coding blocks might you use when acting out a story?
  2. How is a computer program like a story?
  3. Throughout a story, characters express mood and emotion. How can you program these into the story?
  4. What types of coding blocks might you use to show a math problem or to tell a math story?

folder.name: Explore - Gravity Maze: Gravity Word Problems

instructions.text:
Explore Gravity Maze and its tools. Answer the following questions:

  1. What do you already know about gravity? 
  2. How do you think gravity would affect a marble traveling on a marble run?
  3. What do you think can speed up or slow down a moving object?
  4. What do you already know about measurement?

folder.name: Plan and SMART Goal - Gravity Maze: Gravity Word Problems

instructions.text:
Before you start the challenge, make a plan for your project and set a SMART goal. Your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.

  1. Practice stacking tower pieces and watch the ball roll from one to the next so you can see how they work together. Try putting some towers on their sides. Which pieces are best used vertically? Which pieces can be used on their sides? 
  2. Think about how gravity pulls down on objects. In a marble run, think about the role of gravity in helping the marble reach the bottom. 
  3. Examine all of the pieces in the Gravity Maze kit. What units of measure can you use to describe the pieces?
  4. Think about how you would measure the distance a ball travels to reach the bottom of a Gravity Maze. Decide which unit of measure you would use, and which measuring tool would work the best. Is the distance best measured in meters, centimeters, yards, or inches?
  5. Write your project SMART Goal: We will use (name of technology) to (detailed description) by (due date). We are creating this because (personal interest or purpose).

folder.name: Project Submission - Gravity Maze: Gravity Word Problems

instructions.text:
For your project submission share the following items:

  1. Upload your measurement word problems. Make sure to include pictures of number lines or diagrams used to solve your problems.
  2. Upload images of the challenge cards you tried and your solutions even if your solutions did not work. Include the measurements you collected, number lines or diagrams, and the related word problems and solutions.
  3. Choose two or three challenge cards that you think were particularly hard to solve and explain the following:
    • How did gravity work to bring the ball down to the Target Tower?
    • What did you try to do originally, and how did you change your tower arrangement to make it work?
  4. Reflect on the following questions:
    • Why can you get measurements with fewer errors when using the metric system? 
    • How did you use measurements when constructing your mazes? How did you use math when comparing the results of different mazes?
    • Gravity has the same “pull down” on all balls that have the same mass. What makes a ball speed up or slow down in a maze? Which Challenge Card resulted in the ball moving the fastest? What was different about that maze?
    • Which Challenge Card was the easiest for you to solve? What made it easy for you?
    • Which Challenge Card was the most difficult task for you to solve? What made it difficult?
  5. Revisit your SMART goal. Remember, your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.
    • Did you meet your SMART goal? Why or why not?
    • How did you manage your time? How could you improve your time management?
    • Did you have to modify your SMART goal?
    • What will you do differently next time?

  3. How will you research the objects you select? Will books or the internet be your best resource? Why?

folder.name: Plan and SMART Goal - Ozobot: Measure a Maze

instructions.text:
Before you start the challenge, make a plan for your project and set a SMART goal. Your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.

  1. Look at a ruler. What do the marks on a ruler mean? Look at a ruler and find the quarter-inch, half-inch, and whole-inch marks.
  2. Draw lines of various lengths. Practice measuring the lines to the quarter, half, or whole inch marks on your ruler.
  3. Draw a line plot with a horizontal scale that includes ¼’s, ½’s, and whole numbers.
  4. Consider what a shape is. How can you group shapes?
  5. Write your project SMART Goal: We will use (name of technology) to (detailed description) by (due date). We are creating this because (personal interest or purpose).

instructions.text:

  4. Reflect on the following questions:
    • What details and strategies did you use to make your instructions clear?
    • Which steps were the most challenging to write? How did you try to make your instructions clearer?

    • How do the parts of an inch, marked by the small lines on the ruler, help when describing your maze?
    • What shapes did you use in your design? What additional shapes could you have used?

instructions.text:
Before you start the challenge, make a plan for your project and set a SMART goal. Your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.

  1. Identify the purpose of your presentation - Will you be teaching them a skill? Will they need to write? Draw? Recite? Act out?
  2. Do some research to learn about what preschool children know. Good lesson writing requires you to know what your learner knows and then reinforce and build on it. If you don’t know any preschoolers, ask your parents about you when you were a preschooler. Or interview  school teachers of young children about what you should expect them to understand.
  3. Review books written for children or watch videos of preschool lessons to get an idea about how to design lessons for young children.
  4. Write your project SMART Goal: We will use (name of technology) to (detailed description) by (due date). We are creating this because (personal interest or purpose).

folder.name: Plan and SMART Goal - Scratch: Program to Solve Word Problems

instructions.text:
Before you start the challenge, make a plan for your project and set a SMART goal. Your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.

  1. Watch YouTube tutorials on the Scratch official YouTube channel: Scratch Tutorial These tutorials will give you ideas for inserting or replacing blocks within a script to change a program.
  2. Think about a way to incorporate multiplication or division in your Scratch animation. Will one character share a word problem and another answer it? Will your characters act out a word problem while someone else narrates? Will one character teach another how to figure out an unknown whole number in a multiplication or division equation? Do you have another idea you would like to try? You will use a green multiplication or division Operator block in your program. How do you plan on using that block? What role will it have in your program? Here are a couple of ideas:
    • You could control how your sprite moves by putting a green Operator block into a blue Motion block to command the sprite to move certain distances. 
    • You could put a green Operator block into a purple Looks block to make your sprite say the product of two numbers.
  3. Write your project SMART Goal: We will use (name of technology) to (detailed description) by (due date). We are creating this because (personal interest or purpose).

folder.name: Plan and SMART Goal - Snap Circuits Rover: Night Rover

instructions.text:
Before you start the challenge, make a plan for your project and set a SMART goal. Your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.

  1. Review the components needed to build the Night Rover. You may want to review page 4 of the instruction manual, “About Your Snap Circuit Parts,” to learn more about how these components work.
  2. Review the “DO’s and DON’Ts of Building Circuits” on page 7 to ensure that you do not create short circuits.
  3. Your Rover will need to locate as many “Mars rock samples” as it can in a set amount of time. One partner should spread out the rock samples on the floor of your lab or another space identified by your facilitator. The other partner should plan the driving route so that the Rover can “collect” as many samples as possible before time runs out. (All partners should take turns with each responsibility.)
  4. Predict the fraction of “Mars rock samples” your Rover will be able to collect in the given amount of time.
  5. Write your project SMART Goal: We will use (name of technology) to (detailed description) by (due date). We are creating this because (personal interest or purpose).

instructions.text:

  1. Walk around the room. Think about every turn and how many steps you took.

    • Did you have the same number of steps for each side of the room?
    • Could you tell a blind person how to follow your path?
  2. Write down the steps you took and see if someone else could follow your path exactly. If they can't, think about what you can add to your instructions to make them clearer. This is good practice for when you will need to write instructions for Sphero to follow.
  3. Write your project SMART Goal: We will use (name of technology) to (detailed description) by (due date). We are creating this because (personal interest or purpose).

    • These line plots tell you the number of newly infected robots at given intervals. You used the line plot data to find total infected robots at the given intervals and average number of infected robots at the given intervals. You saw a different line plot example in the What You Should Know section. What other types of data could you collect with a line plot? What additional data could you solve for, using the line plot data?
    • What did you learn about the spread of infectious diseases? What can be done to prevent the spread of disease?

instructions.text:
Before you start the challenge, make a plan for your project and set a SMART goal. Your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.

  1. Using the symbols described in the Circuit Drawing section in the What You Should Know tab, create two drawings - one of an open circuit and one of a closed circuit. Label your drawings. These will be uploaded in your project submission.
  2. Review the Squishy Circuit Instruction Manual. Are there any important pieces of information to know when using the Squishy Circuit kit?
  3. Write your project SMART Goal: We will use (name of technology) to (detailed description) by (due date). We are creating this because (personal interest or purpose).

folder.name: Project Submission - Squishy Circuits: Series and Parallel Circuits

instructions.text:
For your project submission share the following items:

  1. Upload the circuit drawings (open, closed, series, parallel) you created
  2. Upload the pictures of your series and parallel circuits.
  3. Upload your Venn Diagram comparing series and parallel circuits.
  4. Reflect on the following questions:
    • What are the advantages and disadvantages of using series circuits? What are the advantages and disadvantages of using parallel circuits?
    • Did adding extra LEDS affect the series circuit? Did they affect the parallel circuit? Describe.
    • Make a prediction about what would happen to current if you added a motor or buzzer to a series circuit? To a parallel circuit?
  5. Revisit your SMART goal. Remember, your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.  
    • Did you meet your SMART goal? Why or why not? 
    • How did you manage your time? How could you improve your time management? 
    • Did you have to modify your SMART goal? 
    • What will you do differently next time?

folder.name: Explore - Squishy Circuits: Explore Switches and 2D Shapes

instructions.text:
Explore Squishy Circuits and its tools. Answer the following questions:

  1. What types of switches do you have in your house? What are they used for?
  2. What have you built with dough or modeling clay in the past? Why might you use dough when building circuits?
  3. How would you sort two-dimensional shapes?
  4. Where can you find lines that form a square corner—like the edge of a piece of paper—in the real world?
  5. Where can you find lines that never cross or intersect in the real world?

folder.name: Plan and SMART Goal - Squishy Circuits: Explore Switches and 2D Shapes

instructions.text:
Before you start the challenge, make a plan for your project and set a SMART goal. Your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.

  1. Which type of resistor would you use in your design, a buzzer or motor? Sketch different diagrams to model how you might design your circuits.
  2. Which shapes would you need to include in your design?
  3. What creative designs could you make with those shapes? Would you want to create something abstract from your imagination, or something you may find in real life?
  4. What types of lines and angles might you need to include in your design?
  5. Write your project SMART Goal: We will use (name of technology) to (detailed description) by (due date). We are creating this because (personal interest or purpose).

folder.name: Project Submission - Squishy Circuits: Explore Switches and 2D Shapes

instructions.text:
For your Project Submission share the following items:

  1. Upload the sketch of your design and an image of your closed-circuit creation. Use the following checklist to be sure all parts of the challenge are uploaded:
    • A sketch of the design that includes at least 6 shapes.
    • At least one of each of the following shapes are included in the design: a right triangle, a parallelogram, a rectangle, a rhombus, and a trapezoid.
    • Each of the different shapes in the sketch are outlined using a different color for each type of shape (e.g. all isosceles right triangles are blue). 
    • A key is included at the bottom of the sketch. See step 2 under Sketch Your Design for details about what should be included in the key.
    • The added buzzer or motor is clearly labeled and circled in the sketch.
  2. Upload Photo of your closed-circuit creation:
    • Take a picture of the design after being built with dough.
    • Use a photo editor to circle the circuit components in the image before uploading. Or, describe in words where we can find these components.
    • Use a photo editor to outline a few of the visible shapes that are in both your sketch and in the final dough creation. Or, describe in words where we can find these shapes.
    • If you built a separate combination circuit, take a photo of that as well and describe which resistors you used and where they are located in your dough creation.
  3. Reflect on the following questions:
    • Was it easier to incorporate the two dimensional shapes when thinking about their specific attributes rather than thinking about the shape, in general? Why or why not?
    • Did you have to revise your sketches as you built? How? Did you think it helped to sketch prior to building? Why or why not?
    • How many times did you have to revise your circuits before they worked correctly?
    • Which resistors did you choose to include in your circuit with multiple resistors? Did they both start at the same time when the switch was turned on or did one start after the other? Why did you think that happened?
  4. Revisit your SMART goal. Remember, your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based. 
    • Did you meet your SMART goal? Why or why not?
    • How did you manage your time? How could you improve your time management?
    • Did you have to modify your SMART goal?
    • What will you do differently next time?

instructions.text:

    • What problem can you solve by using a drone to deliver or collect an item?

    • Where will your drone have to travel? What is that environment like?

folder.name: Plan and SMART Goal - Tinkercad: 3D Design to Size

instructions.text:

  1. What might you like to design and build? Is there something you need to fix or want to make that would help somehow? 
    • Perhaps a missing Lego piece for your unfinished model or a pencil holder for your desk? You may want to look through some of the other projects students have made using Tinkercad. 
  2. Create a sketch of what it is you want to create will help when using the Tinkercad software to design your object.
    • What shapes might you use? What colors?
  3. Will you be printing a model of something large or small?
    • If so, how can you determine how large or small to design your object?
  4. How are measurements converted in the metric system?
    • What happens to the decimal point in a number when either multiplying or dividing by a power of 10?
  5. Write your project SMART Goal: We will use (name of technology) to (detailed description) by (due date). We are creating this because (personal interest or purpose).

folder.name: Explore - UKIT Beginner: Walk the Line

instructions.text:
Explore UKIT Beginner and its tools. Answer the following questions:

  1. What does the UKIT Beginner kit allow you to do?
  2. How does the app work to control the robots?
  3. What do you notice about UKIT Beginner? What would you like to understand more?

folder.name: Assignment- Plan and SMART Goal - UKIT Beginner: Walk the Line

instructions.text:
Before you start the challenge, make a plan for your project and set a SMART goal. Your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.

  1. How will you use measuring tools to gather your data?
  2. What resources will you need to create and program the robotic car?
  3. How will you collect your data? How will you organize your data?
  4. Write your project SMART Goal: We will use (name of technology) to (detailed description) by (due date). We are creating this because (personal interest or purpose).

folder.name: Daily Project Journal - UKIT Beginner: Walk the Line

instructions.text:
Use this space to answer the following questions every day by collaborating with your partner - this is a group assignment.

  1. What did we do today?
  2. What did we learn?
  3. What math did we use?
  4. What could we have done differently?
  5. What new questions do we have based on our work today/this week?
  6. What is our plan for next time?

folder.name: Project Submission - UKIT Beginner: Walk the Line

instructions.text:
For your project submission share the following items:

  1. Upload the Robot Measurement and Program screenshot for the program that you altered to make the robot travel twice as far.
  2. Upload the Random Number Generator Data Table and Line Plot.
  3. Reflect on the following questions:
    • What was the hardest challenge you faced while building the robot?
    • What was the hardest challenge you faced while programming the robot?
    • Why are line plots used to display data? Did creating a line plot help you to understand the data you collected?
    • Think about self-driving cars.  How do you think the computers in those cars work to ensure the passengers are safe?  What types of programs would the programmers have to include?
    • If you had to run this experiment again, what would you change and why?
  4. Revisit your SMART goal. Remember, your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.  
    • Did you meet your SMART goal? Why or why not? 
    • How did you manage your time? How could you improve your time management? 
    • Did you have to modify your SMART goal? 
    • What will you do differently next time?

folder.name: Project Submission - UKIT Beginner: Ace in the Hole

instructions.text:
For your project submission share the following items:

  1. Upload the following items:
    • Upload a screenshot of a program showing how you altered the angle.
    • Upload a copy of your Data Table of angles and distances you measured.
    • Upload your Claim-Evidence-Reasoning. 
  2. Reflect on the following questions:
    • Did the angles you measured with the protractor change during testing? 
    • How did the angles of the protractor and the programmed angles match or differ? Explain. 
    • What limitations are there to using a protractor? To relying on the program to determine the angle?
    • If you were a golfer who wanted to make a long shot, what angle would you use and why?
    • If you were a golfer and you wanted to make a short putt, what angle would you use and why?
    • If you had to run this experiment again, what would you change and why?
  3. Revisit your SMART goal. Remember, your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.  
    • Did you meet your SMART goal? Why or why not? 
    • How did you manage your time? How could you improve your time management? 
    • Did you have to modify your SMART goal? 
    • What will you do differently next time?

instructions.text:

  1. What will be the best way to ensure that the robotic car moves forward the number of spaces to the desired location?

  3. Why should you only use one servo for steering?
  4. How do you make the robotic car turn?
  5. Write your project SMART Goal: We will use (name of technology) to (detailed description) by (due date). We are creating this because (personal interest or purpose).

folder.name: Project Submission - UKIT Beginner: Find Your Way

instructions.text:
For your project submission share the following items:

  1. Upload the following items:
    • A picture of your grid.
    • A screenshot of at least one of the programs you wrote for the code from the origin activity. 
    • Create a coordinate plane and trace the path that Freda took through her neighborhood. 
  2. Reflect on the following questions:
    • How is using a coordinate plane to map points useful? What is a real world application of this mathematical process?
    • Think about self-driving cars. How would using a coordinate grid help them to program the car to reach a given destination?
    • Programmers often do not achieve success the first time they code a project. Did you face this difficulty? How did you work around this?
    • How did the criteria and constraints of the project make it easier? How did they make it more difficult?
  3. Revisit your SMART goal. Remember, your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.  
    • Did you meet your SMART goal? Why or why not? 
    • How did you manage your time? How could you improve your time management?

    • What will you do differently next time?

folder.name: Explore - Graphic Design with Vectr: Character Art Symmetry

instructions.text:
Explore Vectr and its tools. Answer the following questions:

  1. Draw a simple stick figure. Draw a vertical line through the middle of your figure. Describe what you notice on both sides of the line.
  2. Draw a horizontal line through the middle of your figure. Now what do you notice?
  3. See if you can draw another object that will have the same results as when you drew the vertical line through your stick figure.
  4. Fold a piece of paper in half. See if you can draw a shape that is the same on both sides of the fold.

folder.name: Plan and SMART Goal - Vectr: Character Art Symmetry

instructions.text:
Before you start your challenge, make a plan for your project and set a SMART goal. Your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.

  1. Make a sketch of the ideas you already have for your character.
  2. Label your sketch with which parts of your character will have line symmetry and which parts will not.
  3. What details will you add to your character to give it a certain style?
  4. Write your project SMART Goal: We will use (name of technology) to (detailed description) by (due date). We are creating this because (personal interest or purpose).

folder.name: Project Submission - Vectr: Character Art Symmetry

instructions.text:
For your project submission share the following items:

  1. Upload a screenshot of your character and your Line Symmetry Analysis table.
  2. Reflect on the following questions:
    • What types of symmetry did you find in your character?
    • How did the parts of your character with symmetry change the character's style?
    • How did the parts of your character without symmetry change the character's style?
    • How does the Vectr tool help you to draw shapes that are symmetrical?

folder.name: Explore - Vectr: Edit and Scale Images

instructions.text:
Explore Vectr and its tools. Answer the following questions:

  1. How are multiplication and division related?
  2. When is the product of a whole number and fraction larger than the whole number? When is the product smaller than the whole number?
  3. What happens when you ‘zoom in’ on an image on your device, computer, tablet, or cell phone?
  4. What tools do you notice in Vectr? How could they help you?
  5. Why would it be helpful to be able to resize a picture?

  2. How much larger or smaller do you want to make your picture? What size do you want it to be when printed? How will you make sure that your printed image is the right size?
  3. Write your project SMART Goal: We will use (name of technology) to (detailed description) by (due date). We are creating this because (personal interest or purpose).

folder.name: Explore - Vernier Elementary Energy Efficiency: Save Energy at School

instructions.text:
Explore Vernier Elementary Energy Efficiency and its tools. Answer the following questions:

  1. How do light bulbs differ from each other? What can you learn about light bulbs with a sensor?
  2. What do you notice about the senor? How do you think it works?
  3. What will the data we collect tell us? How can we use the data?
  4. How could we organize and display the data from the light bulbs in our school?

folder.name: Plan and SMART Goal - Vernier Elementary Energy Efficiency: Save Energy at School

instructions.text:
Before you start the challenge, make a plan for your project and set a SMART goal. Your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.

  1. Locate the light bulbs you are interested in collecting data from. Which areas of the classroom have bulbs that can be measured? What types of bulbs do you predict will be in each area?
  2. Think about which areas of the classroom you feel need the brightest light. Which areas of the classroom would be good locations to conserve energy?
  3. Create a data collection chart to collect the location of bulb, type of bulb, and lumen level. 
  4. Write your project SMART Goal: We will use (name of technology) to (detailed description) by (due date). We are creating this because (personal interest or purpose).

instructions.text:

    • The light bulb above the sink uses 500 lumens. The lightbulb in the overhead light uses 610 lumens. Compared to the bulb above the sink, how many more lumens are used in the overhead light?
    • The light bulb in the reading table lamp uses 530 lumens. The light bulb in the overhead light uses 90 more lumens. How many lumens are used in the overhead light?
  3. Revisit your SMART goal. Remember, your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.

instructions.text:
Explore Vernier Elementary Energy Efficiency Collection and its tools. Answer the following questions:

  2. How does Vernier Graphical Analysis show the data you collect?
  3. What patterns do you notice as you measure the amount of light in your SmartLab HQ or classroom?
  4. Have you been anywhere with hot temperatures? What type of clothing were you most comfortable in and why? 
  5. Have you been anywhere with cold temperatures? What type of clothing were you most comfortable in and why?

folder.name: Plan and SMART Goal- Vernier Elementary Energy Efficiency: Design an Expedition Suit

instructions.text:
Before you start the challenge, make a plan for your project and set a SMART goal. Your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.

  1. Brainstorm a list of possible places to visit, and think about the climate. Hint: The climate is the weather conditions in that area over a long period of time. Is it generally warm or cold? Humid or dry?
  2. Before writing your SMART goal, consider these questions:
    • What do you already know about light and heat?
    • What kinds of clothes do you wear for the climate where you live?
    • If you’ve lived or traveled to another place in the world, how did you dress differently?
  3. Write your project SMART Goal: We will use (name of technology) to (detailed description) by (due date). We are creating this because (personal interest or purpose).

instructions.text:
Explore Vernier Elementary Energy Efficiency and its tools. Answer the following questions:

  1. What kind of information have you seen presented in a pie chart?
  2. What kind of information have you seen presented in a pie chart?
  3. What kind of information do you learn from a protractor?
  4. How is a pie chart useful for giving information?

folder.name: Plan and SMART Goal - Vernier Elementary Energy Efficiency: Keep Our City Cool

instructions.text:
Before you start the challenge, make a plan for your project and set a SMART goal. Your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.

  1. List some resources that you think are essential to the place where you live (e.g. bus stations, parks, grocery stores, and more).
    • What man-made materials make up these resources? (For example, a grocery store may be made of bricks and glass windows, and may be surrounded by an asphalt parking lot.)
    • What are some other man-made surface materials that you could measure?
    • What natural materials make up these essential resources?
    • What other surfaces could you measure that are not man made?
  2. Before you collect data, find out the current temperature. You will want to compare this temperature to the temperatures of the materials. You will also want to note the time of day and weather conditions. Why do you think this information is important?
  3. When making your pie chart, what should the sum of all of your angles be?
  4. Create a chart you can use to collect the data you will add to your pie chart.
  5. Write your project SMART Goal: We will use (name of technology) to (detailed description) by (due date). We are creating this because (personal interest or purpose).

folder.name: Project Submission - Vernier Elementary Energy Efficiency: Keep Our City Cool

instructions.text:
For your project submission share the following items:

  1. Upload screenshots of your data tables, pie charts, including the measurement of each angle. Make sure the location description or name, air temperature, time of day, and weather conditions are noted on your data tables. 
  2. Reflect on the following questions:
    • What does the size of each piece in your pie chart tell you about the surfaces in the area?
    • Will any group’s pie chart be the same as anyone else’s? Why or why not?
    • Would you rather describe the surfaces that make up the area you chose in words, tables, or by using the pie chart? Why?
    • How did you use angle measurements to create your pie chart? Use math vocabulary in your explanation.
    • How does the air temperature compare to the material temperatures?
    • How do you think the temperatures may have differed if you took your measurements earlier or later in the day? Why?
    • Describe how you used the data from the infrared thermometer to decide what changes to make to the surfaces in your area.
    • Compare your two pie charts. How are they similar and different? Explain your recommendations for changing the types of materials used in your chosen area.
  3. Revisit your SMART goal. Remember, your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.  
    • Did you meet your SMART goal? Why or why not? 
    • How did you manage your time? How could you improve your time management? 
    • Did you have to modify your SMART goal? 
    • What will you do differently next time?

folder.name: Project Submission - Vernier Elementary Energy Efficiency: Energy Saver or Energy Consumer

instructions.text:
For your project submission share the following items:

  1. Upload a copy of your completed Energy Saver Survey.
  2. Upload your appliance energy usage calculations and comparisons.
  3. Upload your average state energy usage calculations and comparisons.
  4. Upload an image of your poster, brochure, flyer, or presentation with your calculations, comparisons, and any other facts, data, charts, and/or images that help support your argument.
  5. Reflect on the following questions:
    • Think about your appliance comparisons. 
      • Did you learn anything new by calculating and comparing the daily energy usage of the different appliances? 
      • Did the energy usage of any of the appliances surprise you? Why or why not?
    • Consider the average household’s energy use in your state
      • Why do you think your state uses more or less energy than the other states you chose? What factors affect your state’s energy use?
      • What can homes in your state do to be more energy efficient? Or, if you live in a more energy efficient state, what are people in your state already doing to help reduce energy use?
    • What do you believe to be the biggest benefit to reducing the amount of energy someone uses on a daily basis?
  6. Revisit your SMART goal. Remember, your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.  
    • Did you meet your SMART goal? Why or why not? 
    • How did you manage your time? How could you improve your time management? 
    • Did you have to modify your SMART goal? 
    • What will you do differently next time?

  2. How do you collect data in the Vernier Graphical Analysis software program?

folder.name: Plan and SMART Goal- Vernier Elementary Sensing Science Collection: Protect the Animals!

instructions.text:
Before you start the challenge, make a plan for your project and set a SMART goal. Your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.

  1. Sketch your design for the adaptation you will create and test.
  2. Consider these questions:
    • What animal are you going to design an adaptation for? What is their habitat like?
    • What kind of adaptation will you create: body part, body covering, or a behavioral adaptation?

folder.name: Plan and SMART Goal - VEXcode VR: Shape Art

instructions.text:
Before you start the challenge, make a plan for your project and set a SMART goal. Your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.

  1. How can you explain to someone else that this math sentence is true? 9 × 4 = 4 × 9
  2. Think about every step as you draw an array on grid paper. How would you tell someone to draw the same array without seeing yours?
  3. Plan your tessellation. How many shapes do you want? How will you rotate and reflect shapes so they fit together?  A sketch can help you plan.
  4. Write your project SMART Goal: We will use (name of technology) to program (detailed description) by (due date). We are creating this because (personal interest or purpose).

folder.name: Daily Project Journal - VEXcode VR: Shape Art

instructions.text:
Use this space to answer the following questions every day by collaborating with your partner - this is a group assignment.

  1. What did we do today?
  2. What did we learn?
  3. What math did we use?
  4. What could we have done differently?
  5. What new questions do we have based on our work today/this week?
  6. What is our plan for next time?

folder.name: Project Submission - VEXcode VR: Shape Art

instructions.text:
For your project submission share the following items:

  1. Upload the following: 
    • A screenshot of the plan and sketch for both the one-shape and the two-shape tessellations. Include your description of the properties of the shapes.
    • A screenshot of the code you first wrote to create the art and the art the VEX Robot made.
  2. Reflect on the following questions:
    • How did you use multiplication to create your art?
    • Why do some shapes fit together with no gaps? Why do some shapes not fit together?
    • Why must every step have a code for the robot? How did your art look when you forget a step?
    • How did you ‘debug’ the program?
  3. Revisit your SMART goal. Remember, your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.  
    • Did you meet your SMART goal? Why or why not? 
    • How did you manage your time? How could you improve your time management? 
    • Did you have to modify your SMART goal? 
    • What will you do differently next time?

folder.name: Explore - Wixie: Exploring Polygons and Patterns

instructions.text:
Explore Wixie and its tools. Answer the following questions:

  1. What would you guess is the length of the walls of your bedroom? Your living room? How could you measure it? What information would you need to know?
  2. How does the size of your bedroom compare to the size of your living room?
  3. How does the area of your bedroom compare to the area of your living room?
  4. What patterns have you noticed around you?
  5. Describe a pattern that you have seen using the same image that has changed direction.

folder.name: Plan and SMART Goal - Wixie: Exploring Polygons and Patterns

instructions.text:
Before you start the challenge, make a plan for your project and set a SMART goal. Your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.

  1. How will you decide which shapes to use in your pattern?
  2. Will you rotate or reflect the shape, or both?
  3. How will you find the perimeters of your rectangles?
  4. How will you find the areas of your rectangles?
  5. Write your project SMART Goal: We will use (name of technology) to (detailed description) by (due date). We are creating this because (personal interest or purpose).

folder.name: Project Submission - Wixie: Exploring Polygons and Patterns

instructions.text:
For your project submission share the following items:

  1. Upload a screenshot of your rectangle/ polygon pattern.
  2. Upload a screenshot of your rectangle and other polygon perimeter and area.
  3. Reflect on the following questions:
    • What is the perimeter measurement?
    • What is the area measurement?
    • How did you use the ruler to find the perimeter and area?
    • How can you make two rectangles with the same perimeters, but different areas?
    • How can you make two rectangles with the same areas, but different perimeters?
    • How do you think you could find the perimeter of a curved object or shape?
    • How are reflections and rotations helpful to make patterns?
  4. Revisit your SMART goal. Remember, your goal should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time Based.
    • Did you meet your SMART goal? Why or why not?
    • How did you manage your time? How could you improve your time management?
    • Did you have to modify your SMART goal?
    • What will you do differently next time?
